Every Goldhelm child is taught the same origin myth: their ancestors looked at magic and chose not to submit to it. They chose to surpass it.

The Goldhelms â€” Solari in their own refined Solaran-script tongue â€” did not always exist as a distinct race. They were once Folkwynd, the common human lineage of Criozevan. The divergence was not biological accident but ideological design: a civilization so committed to order, precision, and technological supremacy that over generations it physically, culturally, and genetically remade itself.

Appearance & Traits

Goldhelms stand over six feet â€” noticeably taller and more broadly built than average Folkwynd. Their most striking features are golden eyes â€” a trait that appeared within a few generations of the raceâ€™s ideological divergence â€” and ivory-blond hair paired with fair, almost luminous skin. These features are so consistent that Goldhelms born outside the kingdom are immediately identifiable.

They live roughly a century, and spend that century in relentless pursuit of social ascension.

Culture & Society

Goldhelm society is built on a four-tier caste: Citizen â†’ Officer â†’ Ascendant â†’ Architect. Social mobility is possible, even expected, but it requires achievement â€” military service, scientific contribution, or demonstrated excellence in assigned work. The obsession with rising through the hierarchy is simultaneously Goldhelm cultureâ€™s greatest strength and its central dysfunction.

They are deeply isolationist. Outsiders are not merely unwelcome â€” they are viewed as lesser, potentially contaminating. The kingdomâ€™s geographic position, surrounded by natural water barriers and controlled crossings, reinforces this psychology. A Goldhelm who leaves the kingdom and returns changed is treated with deep suspicion.

Holidays: Holo-tech Day celebrates the invention of holotech â€” the single achievement Goldhelms consider their greatest contribution to Criozevan. Founding Day commemorates the establishment of the kingdom in Ovodon, viewed as the moment the Solari became more than humans.

Magic & Technology: The Anti-Magic Nation

Magic is completely banned inside the Goldhelm Kingdom. Use is punishable by public execution. This is not mere law â€” it is theology. The Path of Radiant Order holds that magic is surrender: an admission that the user cannot achieve through skill and intellect what a rune or incantation can achieve through supernatural shortcut.

Holotech â€” holographic and photonic technology developed over centuries â€” serves every function that magic serves elsewhere. Holo-war axes that can cut stone, holo-armor that deflects physical and limited magical damage, holo-shields that project force fields, holo-tech bows, hover-rails for transportation: the Goldhelm Kingdom functions entirely without magic, and thrives doing so.

The secret underground labs in Ibeson suggest that some experimentation continues beyond public doctrine â€” what exactly is being tested beneath Ibesonâ€™s streets is known only to the Goldhelm government.

Military

The army mirrors Roman formations in tactical design: Brutes (heavy frontline, holo-war axes), Archers (holo-tech ranged), Swordsmen (standard infantry), Spearmen (anti-cavalry), and Medics (holotech-based field support). Coordinated holo-units operate on tactical grids. Flanking, shield-wall, and coordinated encirclement are the doctrines of the Auric Vanguard, Goldhelmâ€™s military force.

The Golden War

The Golden War was a civil war between the North and South of the kingdom â€” between Ovodon and Ibeson. Its causes and precise history are not documented in full in public records; the kingdomâ€™s government has suppressed detailed accounts. What is known: the war was fought, and the north won, reinforcing Ovodonâ€™s position as the political seat and the gilded Cradle as the throne of the Goldhelm Family.
